iterm2.api_pb2 module¶

iterm2.asyncws module¶

class iterm2.asyncws.AsyncWebsocketApp(url, on_message=None, on_error=None, on_close=None, subprotocols=None)[source]¶

Bases: websocket._app.WebSocketApp

run_async(sockopt=None, sslopt=None, ping_interval=0, ping_timeout=None, http_proxy_host=None, http_proxy_port=None, http_no_proxy=None, http_proxy_auth=None, skip_utf8_validation=False, host=None, origin=None)[source]¶

run event loop for WebSocket framework. This loop is infinite loop and is alive during websocket is available. sockopt: values for socket.setsockopt.

sockopt must be tuple and each element is argument of sock.setsockopt.

sslopt: ssl socket optional dict. ping_interval: automatically send “ping” command

every specified period(second) if set to 0, not send automatically.

ping_timeout: timeout(second) if the pong message is not received. http_proxy_host: http proxy host name. http_proxy_port: http proxy port. If not set, set to 80. http_no_proxy: host names, which doesn’t use proxy. skip_utf8_validation: skip utf8 validation. host: update host header. origin: update origin header.

iterm2.depfuture module¶

class iterm2.depfuture.DependentFuture(parent, create_inner)[source]¶

Bases: iterm2._future.Future

If you have a future A and you want to create future B, but B can’t be created yet because the information needed to make it doesn’t exist yet, use this. This provides a future C that creates B when A is realized. Its get() blocks until A and B are both realized.

get()[source]¶

Waits until both the parent and the subordinate futures (A and B) are realized. Return’s B’s value.

iterm2.dispatchq module¶

class iterm2.dispatchq.AbstractDispatchQueue[source]¶

Bases: object

Facilitates running a function on another thread.

Clients invoke dispatch_async() to run a function on the thread that pulls from this queue.

Owning threads invoke run_jobs() periodically.

dispatch_async(f)[source]¶
run_jobs()[source]¶
class iterm2.dispatchq.IODispatchQueue[source]¶

Bases: iterm2.dispatchq.AbstractDispatchQueue

A dispatch queue owned by a select loop.

The select loop should select on self.read_pipe, which becomes readable when run_jobs has works to do.

notify()[source]¶
run_jobs()[source]¶
class iterm2.dispatchq.IdleDispatchQueue[source]¶

Bases: iterm2.dispatchq.AbstractDispatchQueue

A condition variable-based dispatch queue that adds the ability to wait for a set period of time and notify the condition variable.

Adds a wait API that blocks until there is work to do.

notify()[source]¶
wait(timeout=None)[source]¶

Waits until there is work to do.

timeout: If None, wait indefinitely. Otherwise, don’t block for more than this many seconds.

Returns the number of jobs run.

iterm2.future module¶

class iterm2.future.Future(transform=None)[source]¶

Bases: iterm2._synchronouscb.SynchronousCallback

Represents a value that will become available later.

As this is a subclass of SynchronousCallback, invoke callback() when the future is resolved. Clients call get() when they’re ready to block for a value.

Also has some bells and whistles. When you create a future you can define a transform function that will modify the value.

You can add a “watch” function that gets called asynchronously when the value becomes available.

get()[source]¶

Returns the existing transformed response if available. Otherwise, waits until it is available and then returns it.

idle_spin()[source]¶

Call this before blocking while idle in the main thread.

realized()[source]¶
wait()[source]¶

Blocks until a value is available.

Has the side effect of telling idle observers that we’re about to block.

watch(callback)[source]¶

Adds a watch callback to the future.

The callback will be invoked when the transformed response becomes available.

iterm2.future.add_idle_observer(observer)[source]¶

Adds an idle observer callback. Will be run just before blocking the main thread.

iterm2.synchronouscb module¶

class iterm2.synchronouscb.SynchronousCallback[source]¶

Bases: object

A wrapper around a condition variable.

Contains one bit of state, self.response.

callback(r)[source]¶

Like notfiying a condition variable, but also sets the response to r.

wait()[source]¶

Blocks until there is a response.
